Marie is the co-founder of Behind The Mask, a community dedicated to creating spaces where people can bring their whole selves to work and discuss mental health, neurodiversity, and more. With 15+ years in Talent Acquisition, Marie advocates for neurodiverse individuals and leads with vulnerability. She’s committed to helping organizations break down stigma and build inclusive, flexible, and human-centered workplaces where everyone can thrive.

sessions.title: Demystifying Crypto & Web3: A Technical Journey Through 15 Years of Innovation
sessions.description:
Despite 15 years of groundbreaking innovation in distributed ledger technology, much of the world still equates Web3 with crypto scams or speculative assets. This talk cuts through the noise to explore the technical foundations that make these systems revolutionary for applications beyond cryptocurrency.

We'll examine the evolution of consensus mechanisms from Bitcoin's resource-intensive Proof of Work to modern approaches like Hedera's asynchronous Byzantine Fault Tolerance. You will learn about topics like data structures, smart contracts, tokens, zero-knowledge proofs, and other innovations that enable today's applications.

The session highlights real-world implementations delivering value now, from asset tokenization to supply chain verification. We'll explore how the convergence of distributed systems with AI is laying the foundation for new economic models and industry transformations, so developers can build distributed applications that deliver utility rather than speculation

speakers.bio: Ed is an Engineer and Marketer experienced in advanced vehicle technology, model-based design (MBD), and distributed ledger technologies (DLT). He is passionate about leading interdisciplinary teams, building user-centric solutions, and connecting with developers and organizations in technology sectors. Currently, Ed works at Hashgraph, growing the Hedera network and helping developers get on board with Web 3. He is also pursuing a graduate degree in Management at Harvard.
speakers.tagline: Head of Developer Relations at Hedera

sessions.title: Prompts are boring. Also, avoidable.
sessions.description:
GenAI and LLMs altered a way of working of many developers. 
Typically, we all started by manually fine-tuning prompts and learning how to better express needs to model.
That approach (even though working and useful) is not perfect - models can be updredictable in understanding their task.

Recently, best way of prompting evolves through "Show, not explain" approach into Automated Prompt Engineering.

Due to recent advantages as "Meteor" framework, human is responsible less for a prompt itself, but more for providing training data. 

How far we can get in avoiding prompts? Can we use pure loss functions and hope LLM generates best prompt for himself?

speakers.bio:
Graduated in Mathematics from Wrocław University of Science and Technology.
For last almost 10years working in Data Science, mostly in e-commerce area, having a pleasure to observe world changing from Word2Vec to current LLMs. Also, enjoyed some episodes working as university teacher.
Currently finishing Management post-grad on Warsaw School of Economy.

sessions.title: A Hitchhiker's Guide to Resource Efficient Software
sessions.description:
Today, sustainability and resource efficiency are crucial for both ecological and economic reasons. Reducing CO2 emissions and cutting operating costs are major benefits of this approach. This presentation offers a guide and overview to resource-efficient software development, focusing on actionable strategies.

We'll start with a brief overview of why resource efficiency and sustainability matters in software development. Then, we'll share practical tips for project managers, software architects, and developers to help reduce the resource needs of their systems. These tips will cover various topics and stages of the development process, providing attendees with practical steps they can apply directly.

speakers.bio: Hendrik Lösch is a management consultant and architect at ZEISS Digital Innovation. The focus of his work is on the development and evaluation of software, based on Microsoft technologies. He also enjoys writing and talking about his work as well as his enthusiasm for clean code, software evolution and test automation in its various forms.
speakers.tagline: Management Consultant at ZEISS Digital Solution

sessions.title: Lessons learned from observing a billion API requests
sessions.description:
What if I told you that after studying and analyzing a billion API requests and 15,000 APIs, I found that Javascript APIs are the most insecure APIs?
This talk is about learning from data and patterns. We’ll look at:
How I processed and analyzed javascript APIs. Some cool database queries.
How javascript frameworks rank in API security and design.
What is the definition of a good API design?
Most common design decisions taken by teams that lead to insecure APIs.
What can we learn from other frameworks to build better APIs? Go was mentioned as the most highly used language to build APIs by Cloudflare.
We will take a look at the complications that the AI wave has brought in API design and security.
For anyone building or managing APIs, this talk will provide a clear look at what’s happening across the API ecosystem and what to do about it.

speakers.bio: Pratim Bhosale is a Developer Advocate and a Go GDE. Pratim has worked with multiple startups and MNCs and helped them scale their backend and community. In her leisure time, Pratim writes about builds projects in Go and Rust. She has given talks and workshops at international conferences like GopherCon, DevBCN, Golab and more
speakers.tagline: Senior Developer Experience Engineer at Treblle

sessions.title: Is it (F)ake?! Image Classification with TensorFlow.js
sessions.description:
Like me, do you have a love of baking shows? Is there a particular one you like where you need to identify the cake from a lineup of similar items? As much as I love watching baking shows, I struggle to pick out the cake. Leading me to wonder if I could build a model to better find the cakes for me.

Historically the Machine Learning ecosystem has been dominated by Python. While I'm happy to script in Python, as a frontend engineer my happy place language is JavaScript. Thankfully, I can use Playwright and JavaScript to extract images for classifying, and TensorFlow.js to try and classify images.

Join me, a very much not Machine Learning expert, as I attempt to use pre-existing models to find the cake. I'll also try to build my own image classification model, and use it in a simple web app to see if we can find the cake better than a machine learning model.

speakers.bio:
Carly is a Developer Advocate & Manager at Elastic, based in London, UK. Before joining Elastic in 2022, she spent over 10 years working as a technologist at a large investment bank, specialising in front-end web development and agility. She is a UI developer, who occasionally dabbles in writing backend services, a speaker and a regular blogger.

She enjoys cooking, photography, drinking tea, and chasing after her young son in her spare time.

sessions.title: How Unit Testing Saved My Career
sessions.description:
When I first started programming, debugging unexpected behavior was frustrating—until I discovered unit testing. Testing not only validated my work but also improved my code’s structure. However, as I gained experience, I found that overly complex tests sometimes made things worse. Messy unit and integration tests obscured what was actually being tested, making failures difficult to diagnose and eroding trust in the tests themselves.

In this talk, we will explore how to harness the power of testing without unnecessary complexity. Using JUnit and Mockito, I will demonstrate how to write clear, purposeful tests that align with what you truly need to validate. We will also discuss how writing testable code naturally leads to cleaner, more maintainable, and more readable code.

By the end, you will have a reliable testing strategy that simplifies development and improves code quality—whether you are new to testing or struggling with complex test setups.

speakers.bio: I am a passionate software developer who finds it important to write good and maintainable code. I value being able to work in teams and find it very important to share knowledge. By combining our knowledge and learning from each other we can achieve much higher goals.

sessions.title: Marko.js: Unsung Hero of Scalable Web Frameworks
sessions.description: Marko.js is a JavaScript framework created by eBay back in 2014. It offers super-efficient server-side rendering, making it ideal for big e-commerce sites and other multi-page apps where speed and SEO really matter. After over 10 years of development, Marko has some standout features that make it an interesting choice. In this talk, I’ll dive into these unique features and showcase some of Marko's innovative solutions. You might not use Marko.js at your company, but there’s still a lot you can learn from it to bring to your next project.

speakers.bio: Engineering Manager @ eBay, ex Frotend Architect @ Marktplaats. Experienced Full-stack Web Developer with 20+ years in the field. Enjoy helping teams to build well-tested, high-performing, and secure software using Javascript, Node.js and React.

sessions.title: Trash Talk - Exploring the memory management in the JVM
sessions.description: In the realm of Java programming, understanding memory management and garbage collection mechanisms cannot only be helpful for optimizing performance and resource utilization but also in general will help you to use the right garbage collector for your application. This session will be about memory allocation, object lifecycle, and garbage collection strategies within the Java Virtual Machine (JVM). Attendees will gain insights into memory allocation strategies, object retention policies, and various garbage collection algorithms like generational and concurrent collection. So when you are interested in getting more knowledge about which garbage collector to use best for your application or about memory management in the JVM, this session is for you.

speakers.bio:
Gerrit Grunwald is a software engineer that loves coding for around 40 years already. He is a true believer in open source and has participated in popular projects like JFXtras.org as well as his own projects (TilesFX, Medusa, Enzo, SteelSeries Swing, SteelSeries Canvas). 
Gerrit blogs regularly at http://harmonic-code.org, he is an active member of the Java community, where he founded and leads the Java User Group Münster (Germany), he is a JavaOne rockstar and a Java Champion. He is a speaker at conferences and user groups internationally and writes for several magazines.

sessions.title: The Evolving Landscape of Application Development: Insights from Three Years of Research
sessions.description: Over the past three years, Docker’s User Research team has conducted an industry-wide survey capturing the evolving experiences, challenges, and trends in application development. Based on insights from thousands of developers, this talk explores key shifts in tooling preferences, working culture, and emerging technologies shaping the industry. We’ll highlight patterns in developer workflows, the impact of containerisation, and how attitudes toward trends like shifted-left security and AI-driven development are changing the application development landscape. Attendees will gain a unique, data-driven perspective on where the industry is headed and the future of software development.

speakers.bio: Julia's work at Docker focuses on improving user experience through mixed-methods research and proactive research strategies. With a PhD in cognitive psychology, Julia brings expertise in quantitative and qualitative data analysis and human-centered research methods, to the tech industry. Prior to joining Docker, Julia was an academic researcher studying memory development and learning.

Olga Diachkova is a Senior UX Researcher working in Berlin, leading cross-product strategic research and evangelizing research process within Docker. With expertise in mixed-methods research, qualitative and quantitative analysis, and communication, Olga has successfully supported multiple products, including Docker Scout. Holding a Master’s degree in Human Factors from Technische Universität Berlin, Olga combines technical expertise with a deep understanding of user behavior to drive business and product decisions.

sessions.title: Why Security-First Development Helps You Ship Better Software Faster
sessions.description:
After leading engineering teams through multiple transformation initiatives, I've learned that one of the biggest misconceptions in our industry is that shipping secure software has to create delivery friction. This session challenges the traditional "develop slow, test lots" mentality by exploring how positioning security and reliability at the beginning of your software development workflow can accelerate delivery. 

Discover how automated security and reliability checks, integrated into your CI/CD pipeline, transform security from a bottleneck into a driver for increased release speed. Learn practical strategies for embedding security-first thinking into modern software systems and hear examples of how teams have shifted security left to ship secure software faster.

speakers.bio: Michael Wildpaner is the VP of Engineering, Security at GitLab, where he focuses on reducing security risks in the software development process and ensures that GitLab’s AI-powered DevSecOps platform delivers optimum value to users and customers. Before joining GitLab, Michael spent over 18 years at Google improving the reliability and security of Google's largest distributed systems. His roles included serving as Uber TL of GCP’s Cloud Identity and Access Protection team, leading Google’s Technical Infrastructure and Security SRE teams, and driving the Managed Open Source Security program.
speakers.tagline: VP of Engineering, Security at GitLab

sessions.title: Responsible AI @ Microsoft - Governance, Standards, Learnings
sessions.description: In this session, we will explain the Responsible AI governance structure at Microsoft, the RAI standard as well as share learnings, e.g. about safety mitigations and red teaming.

speakers.bio: Rebekka Weiß, LL.M. is a fully qualified lawyer and head of regulatory policy at Microsoft Germany. She is the point of contact in the Microsoft Berlin team for data and competition policy, artificial intelligence, digital safety and platform regulation. Rebekka previously worked at the digital association Bitkom from 2017, where she most recently headed the department and team for trust and security. Rebekka studied law in Germany, Switzerland and the United Kingdom. She is co-editor of various legal journals and publishes regularly on the AI Act, data law, IT security law and related fields.
speakers.tagline: Head of Regulatory Policy at Microsoft

speakers.bio: Tobi is a Cloud Solution Architect at Microsoft and led the modernization of data analytics platforms, designing Lakehouse solutions with Fabric and Databricks, and integrating OpenAI technologies like Azure Cognitive Services and Copilot to streamline intelligent workflows. He enabled developer adoption through workshops and hackathons, and drived digital transformation for two major automotive clients. He established Centers of Excellence at DAX companies, developed a Python-based optimization tool (“Force”), and led migrations to Power BI and Fabric. His work emphasized competitive differentiation and close collaboration with Databricks, where Tobi is recognized as a Databricks Insider.
speakers.tagline: Cloud Solution Architect - Data & AI at Microsoft

sessions.title: The Impact of AI on your Workforce: Signal vs Noise
sessions.description: TBA

speakers.bio:
Syed Ali Abbas is Vice President of People – International, SE and HRBPs at
HelloFresh, the largest meal-kit company in the world. In this role, Abbas serves as the
matrix People leader for our SE corporate HQ in Germany plus all HelloFresh markets
around the world excluding North America; and functionally leads the SE HR Business
Partner team supporting our Global / International functions including Tech.

He has previously held various leadership roles in other companies including Group HR
Director for Global Fashion Group, Chief HR Officer for Pacnet Group, Chief Strategy
Officer for Epitome Global and Executive Director of HR for AT&T Inc. Abbas has also
served on Boards in Executive Director, Non-Executive Director and Board Committee
roles. He is an HR Transformation and HR Tech veteran, who also has experience as a
leader, advisor and investor in the HRTech startup space.
speakers.tagline: Vice President of People – International, SE and HRBP at HelloFresh

sessions.title: The End of Unconscious Bias Training. A Scientific Approach to Creating an Inclusive Culture
sessions.description: This session introduces a new paradigm: learning that works at the implicit level. Grounded in neuroscience, this approach drives real behavioural change. Discover how powerful VR experiences can shift unconscious attitudes, build soft skills and deepen self-awareness — creating truly inclusive cultures. And unlike traditional training, it’s measurable — letting you track change as it happens.

speakers.bio:
Charlie has worked for the last decade with the foremost scientists in the field of neuroscience and Virtual Reality. At Kiin, he helps organisations become more empathetic, cohesive and productive using science-based techniques such as implicit learning and embodiment.

Charlie has helped bring change everywhere in sports science, the private sector, public health and social causes. As CEO at Kiin, his mission is to embed this technology deeply into society and enhance closeness between one another.

sessions.title: Fireside Chat with Werner Vogels, VP & CTO, Amazon.com & Daniel Gebler, CTO at Picnic

speakers.bio: Mike Butcher MBE is formerly the Editor-at-large for TechCrunch. He’s also co-founder of Pathfounder editorial events and reports series on ‘impact innovation’, The Europas Awards, TechForUK, TechVets, Techfugees and TechHub. You can follow his writing for TechCrunch here, subscribe to his newsletter here, follow him on Twitter at @mikebutcher, Instagram, LinkedIn, Presubscribe and email him on mike@mikebutcher.me

Daniel Gebler is CTO of Picnic, the world’s fastest growing online supermarket that makes grocery shopping simple,fun, and affordable for everyone. Previously, he was Director R&D of Fredhopper, responsible for the product and technology roadmap, and led engineering teams located in Amsterdam and Sofia. Daniel holds a PhD in Computer Scienceand an MBA. He published papers, edited journals, and chaired international workshops on software correctness.

sessions.title: LLM Local Inference: Tools, Techniques, and Insights
sessions.description:
Over the past few months, I’ve had the chance to work on a research and development project exploring the feasibility of adopting solutions powered by Small and Large Language Models—with one unique twist: inference had to be performed at the edge.

This journey led me to scratch the surface of the vast, fascinating, and rapidly evolving world of LLMs, with a particular focus on inference servers. Along the way, I encountered a fair share of head-scratching moments and valuable insights that I’m excited to share with you.

In this talk, we’ll cover the key concepts behind LLM inference, untangle the tricky jargon, and give you a glimpse into the primary tools and solutions you can leverage if you ever need or want to explore LLM local inference.

speakers.bio: Software Engineer @ xtream, specializing in developing cutting-edge digital products with main focus on backend systems. I am very curious, quickly embracing and letting go of new passions. The only constants in my life have always been software engineering, electronic music, and MTB.

sessions.title: NVIDIA Expert Session: CUDA Developer Best Practices
sessions.description: Visit us at booth A-16 to get answers to your most pressing questions from NVIDIA technology experts, and claim a free self-paced DLI course on July 10-11.

speakers.bio: Lavinia Ghita is a senior solutions architect for the financial services industry (FSI) at NVIDIA. Her work at NVIDIA focuses on applied AI research and driving the adoption of AI-driven technologies in the financial sector. Prior to joining NVIDIA, Lavinia worked on natural language processing research and applications in a quant hedge fund and in big tech.

At NVIDIA, Paul has responsibility for supporting customers and partners in delivering accelerated solutions for the Higher Education, High Performance Computing and AI communities in the UK. As well as providing advice on making the best use of NVIDIA hardware, Paul teaches on how to program for GPUs, mentors at hackathons and regularly engages with research software engineering groups. Paul is an advocate for using accelerated computing in HPC, and the use of AI as a powerful tool for researchers.

Maximilian Stadler is an AI Developer Technology Engineer at NVIDIA, where he optimizes both internal and external AI workloads for NVIDIA GPUs and bridges the gap between field teams and internal product and architecture teams. He holds a M.Sc. in Robotics, Cognition, Intelligence from the Technical University of Munich and is passionate about making AI workloads more efficient as a small contribution to a greener future in a world that is increasingly hungry for data and compute.
speakers.tagline: AI Developer Technology Engineer at NVIDIA

sessions.title: From Workshop to Workspace: The Maker Mindset in Modern DevOps
sessions.description: In this session, we'll explore how the maker movement's core principles align with and enhance DevOps practices. Just as a craftsperson knows their wrenches, hammer, and screwdrivers, successful DevOps professionals must deeply understand their toolchain. Drawing parallels between traditional craftsmanship and modern technology practices, we'll examine how the maker mindset—characterized by curiosity, hands-on learning, and resourceful problem-solving—empowers DevOps teams to build more robust and maintainable systems.

speakers.bio: A software professional currently serving as a Solutions Architect at GitLab, combining deep expertise in DevOps practices with over 8 years of software development experience. Previously led frontend and TypeScript development initiatives and contributed to innovative robotics applications in elderly care. Specializes in software architecture, DevOps transformation, and building scalable solutions.

sessions.title: CRaCing Java Snapshots
sessions.description:
Imagine your Java application starting up in just 5 milliseconds. Sounds incredible, right? Almost too good to be true? And no, this isn’t about native images. There's an innovative solution called Coordinated Restore at Checkpoint (CRaC).

Initially, this concept emerged from the Linux CRIU project: Checkpoint/Restore In Userspace. However, CRIU doesn't always deliver reliable results. That’s where CRaC comes in, offering a JVM-specific implementation.

In this talk, we’ll look into the complexities of CRIU and after that, we will turn to CRaC. We will discuss how CRaC operates within the Java ecosystem, its integration with Spring, and how you can use it in your own applications for near-instant startup times.

From this talk you will learn what is possible to CRaC and what is not, what are the benefits and limitations, and what is the cost of CRaC-ing.

speakers.bio: Years of experience in software engineering and the team's leading roles combined with his passion for Java made Pasha know all the hidden details in this IT niche. As a Developer Advocate for @Bellsoft, he educates the public on the latest software tools built by BellSoft and helps to create and test instruments for developers. He writes in Kotlin, speaks at conferences, composes a new articles, or maintains his pet projects.

sessions.title: LLMOps-driven fine-tuning, evaluation, and inference with NVIDIA NIM & NeMo Microservices
sessions.description:
As the adoption of LLMs continues to grow, the complexity of fine-tuning, and deploying these models has become a significant bottleneck. Manual processes and fragmented workflows can lead to errors, inconsistencies, and delays that hinder innovation and progress. This hands-on workshop introduces LLMOps, an approach to automating the entire LLM evaluation, and inference lifecycle using a GitOps-based methodology.

Participants will learn how to build an end-to-end automated pipeline leveraging NVIDIA NIMs and Nemo Microservices for fine-tuning, evaluation, and deployment of LLMs. Through practical demonstrations, we will explore how to ensure seamless integration, validation, and deployment of updates, leading to faster development cycles, improved accuracy, and increased reliability.

Key Topics: 
- Kubernetes-based LLM Pipelines 
- Argo CD for Continuous Delivery 
- Argo Workflows for LLM Workflow Automation 
- Cloud-Agnostic Deployment

speakers.bio: Anshul is a Sr. Solution Architect at NVIDIA's DGX Cloud team, he specializes in assisting customers with deploying their workloads at scale. Anshul has a strong background in SRE and has extensive experience in managing production-grade Kubernetes clusters across various Cloud Service Providers (CSPs). He has received Ph.D. in computer science from TU Munich, graduating summa cum laude.

sessions.title: Fault Tolerance and Consistency at Scale: Harnessing the Power of Distributed SQL Databases
sessions.description:
Distributed SQL Databases are a powerful new data management technology that addresses modern applications’ need for scalability, availability, geographic distribution, and low response time – with the power of SQL and strong consistency. 

However, distributed databases bring their own challenges. For example, the familiar trade-offs between consistency, high availability, and partition tolerance still exist. Remote data access will still incur speed-of-light network delays.

This talk will describe the inner workings of distributed databases and how to design applications to best exploit their power. Using Oracle and other distributed databases as examples, we will explore the capabilities and unique application challenges posed by distributed databases. This talk will address design patterns that empower applications to handle network latency and consistency in the presence of real-world networks that can and do fail.

speakers.bio:
Wei Hu is the Senior Vice President of Research and Development at Oracle. He leads the development of mission-critical database capabilities as well Blockchain, Kubernetes, AI Microservices, and Globally Distributed Databases.
 
Mr. Hu has B.S. and M.S. degrees from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT). He has been with Oracle since 1998, holds more than 50 patents, and is the author and co-author of several books and papers.

sessions.title: Delegating the chores of authenticating users to Keycloak
sessions.description:
Authenticating users can start simple with a username and a password for each user. But you will also need to handle forgotten passwords and user registration. You might also want to validate email addresses, add second factors, have users update their profile information as needed, or even offer password-less authentication.

A single-sign-on system like Keycloak can handle all that for you and will redirect users after they are authenticated to your applications using the industry standards like OpenID Connect and SAML.

Join this talk to see how you can delegate all the tasks around authentication to Keycloak. We will start simple and enable more and more features in our demo to show the functionality and flexibility of Keycloak. We will also look at features of the latest release and the road map ahead.

speakers.bio: Alexander Schwartz is a Principal Software Engineer at Red Hat working full time as a Keycloak maintainer and technical team lead. At work and in his spare time he codes for Open Source projects. In previous jobs he worked as a software architect and IT consultant. At conferences and user groups he talks about JavaScript front ends, Java back ends, Kubernetes and single-sign-on with Keycloak.
speakers.tagline: Principal Software Engineer at Red Hat

sessions.title: Simplifying edge app delivery: one workflow, thousands of devices
sessions.description: What if deploying to tens of thousands of edge devices was no harder than deploying to one? In this session, we'll explore how Red Hat Edge Manager enables scalable edge app delivery by extending familiar developer workflows. Built on a declarative, agent-based model, it provides full lifecycle automation - including health checks, monitoring, rollbacks, and security enforcement-while integrating seamlessly with your existing tools.

speakers.bio: Christian is a Solution Architect at Red Hat Germany, helping German energy and utilities companies accelerate the energy transition using open source software.
speakers.tagline: Senior Solution Architect at Red Hat

sessions.title: How to Decipher User Uncertainty with GenAI and Vector Search
sessions.description:
User expectations are sky-high, while at the same time users have difficulty articulating their complex needs in a simple search bar on a website. This talk dives into leveraging generative AI and vector search to transform vague user queries into results the user actually wanted, even if they did not know initially what they clearly wanted. We will explore why traditional search methods fall short in grasping user intent and address the common problems users face with ambiguous search queries.

Learn how GenAI generates embeddings to capture the context and semantics of queries, and how vector search optimizes these embeddings using Couchbase. This talk though is not only about the theory. In the talk you will be shown practical examples of how to generate embeddings, and how to set up vector indexes.

See how these advanced search capabilities can transform user interaction and, as a result, business outcomes, making user uncertainty into certainty with GenAI and vector search.

speakers.bio: Ben previously spent a decade in adult education, community organizing, and non-profit management before transitioning to software development. He works as a Senior Developer Advocate at Couchbase and is a member of the board of Ruby Central. Ben is actively involved in open source and writes regularly on the intersection of tech, ethics, and community. He is the author of the book Vector Search with JavaScript, published by Pragmatic Bookshelf.
speakers.tagline: Senior Developer Relations Engineer at Arbitrum

sessions.title: AI Meets Hoare Logic: Revolutionizing Software Testing with Formal Methods
sessions.description:
In the age of AI-driven development, software testing is evolving beyond traditional boundaries. This talk explores how the fusion of Artificial Intelligence and formal verification methods, specifically Hoare Logic, is transforming the way we ensure software correctness.

We will demonstrate how AI can do more than just generate test cases—it can enhance formal verification by automatically inferring preconditions and postconditions through machine learning. By integrating symbolic execution with AI, we move from simple test cases to proof cases, offering mathematically-backed assurances of code correctness.

speakers.bio: I studied Software and Internet Computing at TU Vienna and have over 15 years of experience in the software industry. Starting with Java and JSF, I soon focused on migration projects, where I learned the importance of quality assurance. Later, I shifted to modern architectures, working with cloud-native and hybrid setups to build scalable, resilient solutions. Currently, I’m a Co-founder at Posesio GmbH and an active speaker at meetups and conferences, sharing insights on tech, architecture, and innovation.

sessions.title: Building a framework-independent component library
sessions.description:
In an environment where you work on various projects with different technologies, a frontend library based on WebComponents can help avoid redundant code and create a consistent overall appearance. WebComponents can be integrated in an isolated manner using the Shadow DOM, and Lit, as a lightweight wrapper, eliminates a lot of boilerplate code. 

The process of building a component library with Vite will be implemented step by step using an example component. 

Storybook then allows us to package everything neatly and provides both the code and usage examples of the components in a clear and structured interface.

speakers.bio: I'm a consultant for INNOQ since 2020 with a focus on web technologies. I love to build software and to dip my toes into all kinds of nerdy and unusual topics that help me get a better understanding of things which leads to fun hobbies like brewing my own beer for example.

sessions.title: Harnessing the Power of Open Source's Newest Technologies
sessions.description: In this talk, we’ll explore how the Eclipse Foundation’s latest technologies, including Adoptium, SDV, and Dataspace, are driving innovation and providing strategic value to businesses. We’ll dive into the technical aspects of these projects and examine how open-source solutions can become a competitive advantage in the modern tech landscape. With a focus on real-world applications, I’ll highlight how companies are leveraging these technologies to solve critical challenges, reduce costs, and increase agility. Whether you're a developer or a decision-maker, this session will show you how to harness the full potential of open-source's newest solutions.

speakers.bio: As an experienced leader in B2B Sales, SaaS, and AI, I specialize in aligning strategic business goals with innovative technology solutions. In my current role at the Eclipse Foundation, I focus on driving growth within the tech ecosystem and fostering global partnerships. With over a decade of experience leading cross-functional teams and delivering transformative strategies, my expertise spans AI, data insights, and full-stack development, consistently driving new revenue streams and optimizing business performance.
speakers.tagline: Ecosystem Development Manager at Eclipse Foundation

sessions.title: Beyond the Numbers: Engineering Recruiting Excellence Through Quality, Data, and Team Empowerment
sessions.description:
Do you still think that you need a high number of interviews for successful hiring? Spoiler: You don’t.

In recruiting, more does not equal better!

It’s quite the opposite: A massive amount of candidates in the funnel is not needed to fill a single role and actually can hinder successful recruiting. When you tie up capacity of the interviewing team (recruiters, interviewers & hiring managers), they can’t focus on the actual task: quickly identifying and hiring the right person.

In the session, Christian will highlight the three major elements that sustainably improve recruiting success:

- A well-structured recruiting process
- A focus on the right key figures - thought from end to start
- A well-trained recruiting team

Quality instead of quantity, data-driven recruiting and a strong recruiting team are the basis for successful recruiting. It does not depend on the number of applications, but on a well thought-out approach.

speakers.bio:
Christian Wastlhuber is actually an Egyptologist and should (probably) be looking for mummies. However, he has preferred to use the last 16 years to find people in recruiting who are still alive.
He started out as a sourcer in a recruitment consultancy, worked for a long time in tech start-ups and scale-ups and founded his own company with a business partner at the beginning of the 2024. His focus is on data-driven recruiting processes and strategies, employer branding and a bit of workforce planning. For Christian, all of this is always under the banner of an excellent candidate experience.
speakers.tagline: Fractional Talent Attraction Leader & Data-Driven-Recruiting Evangelist at The UnleashPeople

sessions.title: Attract and Retain Talent: Strategies that Work
sessions.description: In today’s competitive tech landscape, attracting top talent is only half the battle, the bigger challenge is making them want to stay. This panel discussion explores diverse strategies for building and retaining strong tech teams, featuring experts who bring different perspectives from across the industry. From growing teams organically to navigating the complexities of global remote hiring and talent relocation, our speakers will share practical insights into what companies often get wrong, and how to get it right.

speakers.bio: Anastasia Pshegodskaya is Director of Talent Acquisition at Remote, one of the most fast-paced unicorn companies in the world. Before this, she built and led the global sourcing team at GitLab, while previously driving recruiting initiatives at Fortune 500 companies Uber and Dell. Anastasia is extremely passionate about people, and how technology can bring positive change for them — it drives her recruiting career and life.
speakers.tagline: Director of Talent Acquisition at Remote

speakers.bio: Christine is the co-founder of Jetztpat, a company on a mission to make immigration to Germany simple, enjoyable, and fully digital. As an expat herself, with many years of living and working in Japan, she has personally experienced both the joys and challenges of expat life.

With 25 years of experience as a talent expert, Luke Davis is a pioneer of the embedded recruitment model and a trusted leader in global RPO and talent solutions. Passionate about driving innovative hiring strategies, he specialises in delivering flexible, scalable recruitment partnerships worldwide.
speakers.tagline: Head of RPO Solutions at Matchr

speakers.bio: Lead Recruiter at Polarsteps, scaling a Dutch travel‑tech star from 3.5 M to 15 M users. We’ve built a travel app loved worldwide, all through hiring brilliant humans and authentic culture. I geek out on talent density, speak at HR/Talent events (Berlin here we come), and co‑host Lab Days—where designers pitch, marketers code, devs turn into creatives, and the best ideas break free. Let’s build together.

sessions.title: Real-World Security for Busy Developers
sessions.description: Security often gets ignored until something breaks, but it’s a real part of our job as developers. This talk will show specific ways to add security checks and automation at every stage of development: in your editor, during code review, and after deployment. We’ll cover the main security problems developers actually face - like vulnerable dependencies, unsafe code, and leaked keys - and walk through how GitHub’s security tools work in practice. If you write or review code and want to catch issues earlier, this talk is for you.

speakers.bio: Kevin is a Senior Developer Advocate at GitHub, helping senior technical leaders understand and get the most out of the platform. His work in developer relations & experience has spanned tooling, education, and initiatives that support developers to learn and succeed with new technologies. He is a JavaScript developer, avid boardgamer, tired dad of two amazing kids, and shameless Disney adult. He is based in Berlin despite not drinking beer or liking techno.

sessions.title: Say more with less
sessions.description:
How to nail any interview. Talk for developers to get better at presenting themselves and preparing for the interviews. Real tips, best practices and behind the scenes insights that will help developers to become better at searching for the job or getting a promotion. 

Let Alla demystify recruiter behaviours for you. 
Last year I had a line of developers for 1 hour asking me more questions what they can and can't do for CVs, how to talk about gaps in CV or how to negotiate salary with recruiters. Main takeaways will be: practical tips on presenting yourself and successfully bypass recruiters. Recruiters should not be allowed to this session, as I will give away our secrets :-)

speakers.bio:
Alla Pavlova, is a sourcing trainer and Interim Tech Recruiter, based in Amsterdam. Winner of "The most influential sourcer in NL" in 2022. Building tech teams from 2008 for tech startups and gaming companies like Miro, GameHouse, Viber, Dott, Blendle, Relive, and others. Currently scaling Riot Games Singapore and Sydney studios.

Also, she launched and led Slack Community Amsterdam Chapter and she is one of the volunteers who mentor and review CVs in the biggest gaming community.

sessions.title: Fireside Chat with Stephanie Cohen, Chief Strategy Officer, Cloudflare

speakers.bio: Mike Butcher MBE is formerly the Editor-at-large for TechCrunch. He’s also co-founder of Pathfounder editorial events and reports series on ‘impact innovation’, The Europas Awards, TechForUK, TechVets, Techfugees and TechHub. You can follow his writing for TechCrunch here, subscribe to his newsletter here, follow him on Twitter at @mikebutcher, Instagram, LinkedIn, Presubscribe and email him on mike@mikebutcher.me

Stephanie Cohen joined Cloudflare in 2024 as the company’s first-ever Chief Strategy Officer. A seasoned operating executive, she brings more than two decades of experience at Goldman Sachs where she advised the leadership and boards of some of the world's most important companies and institutions. In addition to her time in Investment Banking, she was Goldman Sachs's Chief Strategy Officer, ran two multi-billion dollar global segments and served as a member of their Management Committee.

In her role at Cloudflare, Stephanie leads the company's efforts in expanding the breadth and depth of its presence in boardrooms and the C-suite on its path to $5B in revenue and beyond. Stephanie has a Bachelors of Science in Finance from the University of Illinois.

sessions.title: The AI Hype Filter: What’s Real, What’s Investable, What’s Noise?

speakers.bio: Dr. Nils Eiteneyer is a Partner at Capnamic where they invest in exceptional early-stage tech founders. Before joining Capnamic, Nils co-founded xdeck, a B2B tech boutique accelerator and venture capital firm, and helped scale AEVOR & pinqponq, the sustainable lifestyle consumer goods business at FOND OF Group, as an operator and co-managing director. Nils used to be a consultant at McKinsey & Company and holds a PhD in entrepreneurial finance and innovation from RWTH Aachen University. He studied business economics and social sciences at The London School of Economics and The University of Mannheim. Nils is an advisor turned operator turned investor and very much tries to look at things from a builder and founder perspective.

Stephan has been a Partner at Ventech since 2012 and has more than a decade of venture capital experience. Based in Paris, he drives Ventech investments primarily in the DACH region.  

From his experience he has a unique cross-border perspective, enabling him to explore diverse topics ranging from the application of new business models in both B2B and B2C, to brand-new software applications.  

Beside working on constantly evolving sectors such as: Product Led Growth, Vertical A.I. and Data/API-First driven businesses, he has also been at the forefront of developing Ventech's proprietary AI-software for data-driven opportunity sourcing, the "Ventech Radar," for the last six years. . 

He holds a B.S. in Information Systems, specialized in Software Engineering (HS Flensburg, Germany) and a M.S. in Strategy, Innovation, and Management Control (WU Vienna, Austria), while studying abroad at Bocconi University (Milan, Italy) and Copenhagen Business School (Denmark).

sessions.title: Great DevEx and Regulatory Compliance - Possible?
sessions.description: We are all regulated!  Regulated software delivery faces unique security challenges. Achieving a compliance can be lengthy. Golden pipeline templates, pre-approved and compliant, are crucial. But developers need an easy way to leverage them. Internal Developer Platform (IDP) workflows embed governance and security scanners upfront, streamlining change management. Learn how to accelerate production deployments while ensuring compliance without sacrificing speed. See an IDP in action, enabling teams to balance agility and security in regulated environments. Ideal for developers and managers tackling DevSecOps in regulated environment, this talk showcases solutions for faster, safer application updates.

speakers.bio: With more than 30 years working in software, I feel like I have done all the things. Over that time, working to deliver software at scale, to multiple platforms, with multiple technologies. I am now working with Harness, the modern software delivery platform to enable organisations and teams I used to work in to deliver their software faster, more reliably, cost effectively, and more securely. While constantly, iteratively improving developer experience.

sessions.title: How losing 60 lbs made me a better Platform Engineer
sessions.description: A talk to confuse correlation and causation. During my personal running journey over the last two years, I learned some lessons about endurance running that will also help with creating a developer platform. The secret to success with both is a change in mindset. I will look at many different aspects covering technology, process, organization, and success metrics. This talk will highlight six opportunities to expand the platform as a product approach beyond technology selection and anchor it in continuous learning, community, and the right interfaces. How does all of this relate to my endurance running lessons? Come to find out.

speakers.bio: Markus is a Java Champion, former Java EE Expert Group member, founder of German JavaLand, reputed speaker at Java conferences around the world, and a very well known figure in the Enterprise Java world.
speakers.tagline: Senior Principal Technical Marketing Manager at Red Hat

sessions.title: Green Software Development – Tools, SDK and Patterns for climate friendly applications
sessions.description:
ITC is accountable for 4% of global emissions - fast growing. It is our duty as software developers to utilize our knowledge and position to reduce these emissions.

This workshop is a deep dive into the Green Software. After a detailed introduction to the principles and design patterns, you will be provided with a selection of tools and SDKs to implement these practices.

Specific examples will be used to show how the energy consumption of applications can be measured in different environments.

In this interactive workshop, participants will learn how to optimize their own applications. This includes dynamic scaling and hosting or how load can be shifted to a point in time when there is a lot of renewable energy in the power grid.

Based on the interests of those present, strategies can be found to transform your own applications. A reduction of 40% is realistic in most cases.

At the end of the workshop, everyone should be ready to start developing green software.

speakers.bio:
Aydin Mir Mohammadi, partner and architect at bluehands, has been creating software for more than twenty years. He specializes in the development of distributed complex business applications based on Microsoft technologies. 

Aydin is co-initiator of the .NET User Group Karlsruhe, organizer of the Green Software Development Karlsruhe, and host of the #nossued Open Space. He is also involved in the training of young software developers as a lecturer at the Karlsruhe Cooperative State University.

sessions.title: Use your source code to document your application
sessions.description:
For many development teams, writing and updating documentation can feel like a chore, especially when the codebase changes frequently. While developers often consider the source code as its own documentation, this perspective might not resonate with all stakeholders. Moreover, the source code might not adequately illustrate how different components interact.

What if we could transform our source code into comprehensive documentation that benefits both the team and stakeholders?

In this session, we will explore how to leverage Roslyn to generate documentation directly from your .NET source code. We'll delve into creating diagrams that depict the structure and relationships within an aggregate and sequence diagrams that illustrate the flow throughout the application. We'll render these using file formats such as PlantUML, Mermaid, and Markdown.

speakers.bio:
Michaël Hompus is an Architect and Area Lead at Info Support.

As an architect he is part of several teams, creating new and innovative solutions.
Michaël has many years of development experience with .NET, Java, and Azure.

His passion is to share knowledge with colleagues, customers, and peers.
Microsoft has recognized his efforts for the community by awarding him a Microsoft MVP award.

sessions.title: Better Safe Than Sorry: Preparing for the Next Supply Chain Attack with SBOMs
sessions.description:
Software supply chains are prime targets for cyberattacks, as seen in incidents like Log4J, SolarWinds, and NotPetya, where vulnerabilities in widely used components caused global disruptions. This talk explores how Software Bill of Materials (SBOM) serves as a critical tool in identifying and mitigating security risks across the software lifecycle. By providing transparency into the components of your software, SBOMs enable faster detection and response to emerging threats.

We will cover what SBOMs are, their growing importance in cybersecurity, and how they support regulatory compliance and security frameworks. Additionally, we'll discuss how integrating SBOMs into your DevSecOps pipeline can streamline vulnerability management, reduce response times, and enhance overall software supply chain security. Whether you’re in IT security, software development, or leading strategic initiatives, this talk will offer actionable insights to help you stay ahead of the next supply chain attack.

speakers.bio: Julia Gätjens is a Senior Solutions Architect at GitLab, where she advises customers on implementing DevSecOps best practices. As the leader of the AppSec group within the Solutions Architecture team at GitLab, Julia is deeply passionate about cybersecurity. She is known for her ability to translate complex technical concepts into understandable and practical recommendations.

sessions.title: If You Know Python, You Know Blockchain: Learn How to Create a Python Smart Contract
sessions.description:
In this session, you will learn how to create a complete, functional smart contract using native Python. We'll cover:

- The unique native features of the Algorand blockchain
- How AlgoKit enables you to set up your complete environment in under 5 minutes
- How to use the Algorand blockchain features in real-world applications
- The benefits blockchain can bring to an application

If you ever wondered how to build on blockchain, this workshop is for you. Learn to master the entire lifecycle of decentralized app development and leave ready to create your own Web3 project.

speakers.bio: With over five years of experience in blockchain and fintech, Astha Yadav brings a deep technical understanding and a passion for decentralized technologies to her work. She is dedicated to empowering developers and fostering innovation in the Web3 ecosystem. Committed to making blockchain development more accessible, impactful, and developer-friendly, she actively engages with the community to drive adoption and support builders at every stage of their journey.
speakers.tagline: Senior Developer Relations Advocate at Algorand Foundation

sessions.title: AI at the Edge: Build a Smarter IoT on Arm
sessions.description:
The next wave of AI is happening at the edge – and you’re going to build it. In this workshop, you learn how to run powerful AI on ultra-constrained IoT devices using Arm Ethos-U NPUs, backed by the latest architecture and tools. Walk through real-world workflows to build AI-powered, energy-efficient systems, and preview the new Arm Ethos-U85 making light work of running a GenAI model on FPGA. Bring your laptop and get hands-on with model optimization and deployment using the MobileNet model on the virtualized Arm Corstone reference package, which simulates NPU hardware. By the end, you’ll have the skills (and the toolchain) to start creating intelligent edge AI solutions that deliver high performance without draining power. 

*All workshop attendees are required to bring their own laptop*

speakers.bio: Annie is passionate about empowering developers by making cutting-edge Arm technology accessible and practical. With a strong focus on AI, she specializes in turning complex technical solutions into streamlined, real-world developer experiences.

sessions.title: Agentic GraphRAG with MAGMA (Manifold Agency with Graph Models and Augmentation)
sessions.description:
Like Thanos, graphs are inevitable. Unlike the Snap, graphs expand the possibilities, a literal network effect of effectiveness. Combining multi-agent systems with graph-memory and graph-based tools creates an immensely powerful approach to question-answering, reasoning and workflows.

We'll dive into:
- Planning with a graph
- Remembering with a graph
- Retrieving with a graph
- Putting it all together into a multi-agent graph system

The best part is this isn't all-or-nothing. Graph approaches can be adopted incrementally, fixing corner cases and enabling features. Start simple, connect, repeat.

speakers.bio: Andreas is a technological humanist. Starting at NASA, Andreas designed systems from scratch to support science missions. Then in Zambia, he built medical informatics systems to apply technology for social good. Now with Neo4j, he is democratizing graph databases to validate and extend our intuitions about how the world works. Everything is connected.
speakers.tagline: GenAI Lead for Developer Relations at Neo4j

sessions.title: The Power of AI: A Completely New Perspective to Engineering Management
sessions.description:
The fast changing climate of today requires creative engineering management solutions beyond traditional management methods. With tranditional methods, many difficulties arise, particularly in fields including strategic planning, data-driven decision-making, and efficiency evaluation. This talk will investigate how artificial intelligence may solve problems through data-driven decision-making, real-time insights, and predictive analytics—which are redefining the future of engineering management.

AI-powered engineering management solutions help teams to find problems, streamline processes, and match engineering projects with corporate objectives.    Artificial intelligence may support better management decisions, increase efficiency, and help to improve quality regardless of your role—that of managing a small software team or corporate systems.

speakers.bio: Serdar Bicer is an experienced software engineering leader with a passion for driving innovation and fostering high-performing teams. With over 17 years of experience in the industry, he has a proven track record of delivering impactful solutions and guiding teams through complex technical challenges. He's one of the co-founders and CTO of Valven. Currently, he is dedicated to driving excellence in software engineering teams to achieve their full potential.

sessions.title: 20 Years of Domain-Driven Design: What I’ve Learned About DDD
sessions.description:
Eric Evans’ Domain-Driven Design (DDD) has shaped software development practices for over 20 years, providing a rich toolkit for tackling complex domains. But what truly works, and where do the pitfalls lie? This talk shares key lessons from two decades of applying DDD in real-world projects, offering practical advice for leveraging its most valuable concepts.

We’ll explore the importance of close collaboration with domain experts, techniques for effective modeling, and the often misunderstood role of bounded contexts in structuring systems. The talk also examines the evolving landscape of team collaboration, comparing DDD’s strategic design principles with newer approaches like Team Topologies.

Whether you’re new to DDD or looking to refine your practice, this session will help you focus on what matters most to successfully apply DDD in your projects

speakers.bio: Eberhard Wolff has 20+ years of experience as an architect and consultant - often on the intersection of business and technology. He is the Head of Architecture at SWAGLab in Germany. As a speaker, he has given talks at international conferences and as an author, he has written more than 100 articles and books e.g. about Microservices and Continuous Delivery. His technological focus is on modern architectures – often involving Cloud, Domain-driven Design, DevOps, or Microservices.

sessions.title: From Code to Motion: Building an Autonomous Hat-Hunting Robot with Kubernetes & ML
sessions.description:
Get ready to bring a machine to life - literally. In this session, we'll take you through the end-to-end journey of building an autonomous Raspberry Pi-based robot that can spot a red hat and drive straight toward it. Starting with a vision model trained on diverse images of hats, we’ll explore how to serve ML models efficiently using Kubernetes. Setting up Skupper then allows us to have secure service communication to the robot.

We’ll show how a Python application interfaces with the robot's camera and the object recognition service to convert visual detection into real-world motion control. 

Finally, we’ll demonstrate how to package both the app and ML services into an ARM image with Tekton Pipelines and deploy it directly to the robot via ArgoCD GitOps - enabling it to run fully autonomously without cloud dependencies.

Whether you're a developer, ML engineer, or Kubernetes enthusiast, you’ll leave with practical insights on building intelligent edge devices that bridge the gap between software pipelines and physical automation.

speakers.bio: Daniel Brintzinger is a Principal Solution Architect at Red Hat living in Berlin. He has been working as Developer, Consultant and Software Architect with focus on Service, Integration and Cloud Architectures. Daniel is passionate about Open Source, not just from a technological perspective but also as a cultural shift in the way we work and deliver greatness together.
speakers.tagline: Principal Solution Architect at Red Hat

sessions.title: Prompt API & WebNN: The AI Revolution Right in Your Browser
sessions.description: More and more developers intend to integrate Generative AI features into their applications. Until now, this path has practically always led to the cloud—but it doesn't have to be like that! Currently, various promising approaches exist to running AI models directly on the user's computer. With WebLLM and Chromium's new Prompt API, we can now bring Large Language Models to your Angular app: locally and offline-capable. The W3C's Web Neural Network API (WebNN) will grant AI models access to the device's Neural Processing Unit (NPU). The advantages of these approaches are obvious: Locally executed AI models are available offline, the user data does not leave the device, and all this is even free of charge thanks to open-source models. In this talk, Christian Liebel, Thinktecture's representative at W3C, will present the approaches to make your single-page app smarter. We will discuss use cases and show the advantages and disadvantages of each solution.

speakers.bio: Christian Liebel is a developer with a passion for modern web technologies. He has been recognized as a Microsoft Most Valuable Professional (MVP) and a Google Developer Expert (GDE) and speaks at user groups and conferences worldwide. As a member of the W3C Web Apps working group, he helps push the boundaries of the web.

sessions.title: The Journey of a Pixel in a React Application
sessions.description: Join us as we explore the fascinating journey of a pixel in rendering a React application, starting from the moment a user types a URL into their browser, all the way to the final rendering and interaction phase. We will dive into each stage in detail, covering what happens behind the scenes, why it happens, and how developers can optimize each part for a smoother user experience. This talk will provide insights into key areas like server calls, JavaScript processing, resource fetching, and dynamic rendering. It’s ideal for web developers looking to deepen their understanding of the entire rendering process and find actionable ways to improve application efficiency and performance.

speakers.bio: Shem has more than a decade of experience in software engineering in various domains: client and server-side, real-time systems, big data, mobile, and web. Shem is passionate about building a culture of growth mindset and obsessed with making teams work better together. After several years as a senior IC in WeWork and Meta, Shem is now the CTO and Co-Founder of Wilco, a platform that empowers every developer, regardless of their background or skill level, to unlock their full potential.

sessions.title: From Factory Floor to Kubernetes Core: Building an Edge Platform One Step at a Time
sessions.description:
From bread counting to waste sorting systems - when building a platform for the edge, requirements quickly pile up. The Schwarz Group is a global leader in retail, recycling, and food production through its key divisions Lidl, Kaufland, PreZero and Schwarz Production and therefore plays a critical role for innovation and sustainability across diverse industries. Join us to learn how we built a production-grade edge platform for diverse manufacturing use cases, starting from scratch. 
We'll share our step-by-step journey of evolving from basic machine connectivity to a fully automated, secure, and developer-friendly Kubernetes-based platform. You'll learn about the challenges we faced, the architectural decisions we made, and practical insights on requirements like cost efficiency, security, and high availability.
Whether you're just starting with edge computing or looking to scale your existing solutions, this talk offers real-world lessons from the factory floor.

speakers.bio: Dean is a member of the Industrial Edge Platforms team at Schwarz IT, specializing in cloud infrastructure automation and developing solutions for edge device clusters. Previously, he led the company's IDP integration with Azure Cloud and STACKIT Cloud, focusing on creating cross-platform developer solutions.

Stefan is a Cloud Native Engineer and Architect living near Heilbronn, Germany. He started his career as an IT Business Consultant, translating business requirements into technical specifications for Kaufland's meat processing operations. His Cloud Native journey then took off when he became one of the initial contributors to a self-developed Edge platform serving the divisions Kaufland, PreZero, and Schwarz Production. As team lead and product owner, he is responsible for presenting the platform and its services to various audiences, from upper management to potential customers, while actively participating in the platform's development and the implementation of Industrial IoT use cases.

sessions.title: Robots 2.0: When artificial intelligence meets steel
sessions.description:
The integration of artificial intelligence into robotics is leading to a new era of intelligent autonomous systems. This presentation will explore how advanced AI technologies, including vision-language models (VLMs) and object detection, are enhancing the capabilities of robots in various industries, such as manufacturing, healthcare, and logistics. 
We will highlight key robotic developments, including examples like Figure, X1, and Optimus, discussing their advancements and limitations. A significant focus will be on the challenges of deploying AI on limited hardware, ensuring safety, and facilitating real-world interactions. 
I will also showcase my own robot creation, explaining how VLMs and object detection are used to enhance understanding and interaction with the environment. Join us to discover how AI is reshaping the future of robotics and learn how to leverage these technologies to create smarter, more capable robotic systems.

speakers.bio: As a Microsoft MVP for Azure, Thomas Tomow is actively contributing to the community that is passionate about modern cloud technologies. He hosts Azure Meetups in Konstanz and Stuttgart, Germany, and works as the Chief Technology Officer (CTO) at Xpirit, where he leverages his expertise in cloud, AI, and IoT. In his free time, Thomas practices karate to maintain balance in his life and is always eager to share his knowledge and experience with like-minded individuals.

sessions.title: AI Sovereignty: What Does It Take?

speakers.bio: Clemens Wasner is the CEO of EnliteAI, an Austrian AI venture studio, as well as founder and chairperson of AI Austria, an independent think-tank to promote AI and ensure Austria’s competitiveness in that field. Since 2017 he is releasing the Austrian AI Landscape, a comprehensive overview of AI players in Austria. He is an active member of the European AI Forum, a partnership of like-minded AI organizations which steer regulation in Europe. Before starting his own company he spent more than 10 years in Japan and China, from where he oversaw the Asia expansion as a partner in a management consulting firm.

Boris Hecker is the Managing Director of Atos Germany and in this role, he directs the
strategy and operational execution of the business activities of Atos in Germany. He also
heads the Public Sector and Defense industry in Germany in addition to his overall
responsibility for business growth in Germany, Austria, and Central Europe (Poland and
Czech Republic).

As general manager of STACKIT, Robin Hermann is responsible for developing the Schwarz Group's cloud offering. The business informatics graduate has been loyal to the Schwarz Group for around 25 years and can draw on a wealth of experience from management positions within different entities of the Schwarz Group. With a focus on software engineering and infrastructure technologies, he has successfully advanced the digitization of the Schwarz Group over two decades with a lot of commitment and passion.

sessions.title: AI Won’t Replace Leaders: How Emotional Intelligence Defines the Future of Leadership
sessions.description:
As AI becomes more advanced, traditional authoritarian leadership styles and purely data-driven decision-making are becoming obsolete. AI can optimize processes, but it cannot replace the emotional intelligence (EI) that defines great leadership. This talk will explore:

Why AI is already outperforming poor leadership—but will never replace truly effective leaders.

The critical role of EI in leading international teams in a tech-driven world.

Real-world insights from my MBA thesis research*, including case studies and interviews with leaders.

Practical strategies for integrating AI and EI to build more human-centered, future-proof organizations.

* Topic of My MBA Master Thesis Research: "Key success factors in leading of multinational teams". Through the interviews with leaders  (as part of the research) from different industries and employees there will be certain factors outlined what define true leadership.

speakers.bio: I’m Coach ICF and Mental Trainer with a diverse background that spans law, business development and coaching. Starting as a Law student in Vienna, I transitioned from legal advising to partnership management and eventually found my true passion in coaching. I’m dedicated to helping people realize their potential and grow beyond their limits. Fluent in 4 languages, I bring a multicultural perspective to coaching. Currently I am researching how Emotional Intelligence drives leadership success. I also blend coaching with music with my “Coaching Performances,” to inspire transformation and growth.

sessions.title: The Alpha‑Developer of Tomorrow: Building the Future of the Software Development Lifecycle
sessions.description: At Windsurf, we have a bold goal to accelerate the software development lifecycle by 99%. Every decision we make is focused on optimizing the hundreds of tasks developers handle each day. Through agentic workflows, foundational models like SWE-1, and bold bets on AI-native infrastructure, we’re moving beyond passive tooling. Join Field CTO Alex Laubscher as he shares Windsurf’s vision for an AI-native future and how agentic development is reshaping the alpha developer of tomorrow.

speakers.bio: Alex Laubscher is the Field CTO at Windsurf, where he leads customer strategy and enables enterprises to adopt AI-driven development practices at scale. With deep expertise in deploying AI solutions and a strong background as an engineering leader and entrepreneur, Alex focuses on aligning engineering excellence with strategic business outcomes.

sessions.title: Scrape, Train, Predict: The Lifecycle of Data for AI Applications
sessions.description:
Behind every AI breakthrough lies a critical dependency: fresh, high-quality web data. This session explores the symbiotic relationship between web scraping and artificial intelligence that's transforming how developers build data-driven applications.
Discover how machine learning is solving web scraping's biggest challenges - from bypassing sophisticated anti-bot measures with ML-powered response recognition to building adaptive parsers that automatically handle website structure changes. We'll explore practical use cases: training AI models with scraped data, powering real-time generation systems, and building resilient data pipelines that don't break when websites update.
You'll learn how AI transforms web scraping from a maintenance nightmare into a strategic advantage, whether you're building recommendation engines, training custom models, or creating intelligent data collection systems.

speakers.bio: From debugging servers to building scalable applications, Vidas has seen both sides of the development lifecycle. As a Solution Engineer at Oxylabs, he now combines his Full Stack Developer and Systems Administrator background to help teams overcome their toughest web scraping challenges. His focus on AI-enhanced scraping solutions helps developers build more reliable and scalable data collection systems.

sessions.title: How Lufthansa Industry Solutions is preparing for the Quantum Age!
sessions.description:
With groundbreaking advancements communicated by IBM, Google, Microsoft, and others,
quantum computing is expected to transform industries worldwide. At Lufthansa Industry
Solutions, we’re cutting through the noise to focus on real progress and practical
applications. Join us to explore the current state of quantum technology and discover how
we leverage our deep tech expertise to drive innovation across aviation, logistics, automotive,
and retail sectors. This talk will provide insights into how quantum computing is evolving and
how Lufthansa Industry Solutions is preparing to harness its immense potential to create
competitive advantages and solve complex challenges.

speakers.bio: Julian is a Senior Consultant for Artificial Intelligence and Data Analytics at Lufthansa Industry Solutions. He specializes in applying AI and data analytics to optimize Maintenance, Repair, and Overhaul (MRO) operations, focusing on constraint-based optimization and machine learning. His work combines practical industry solutions with quantum-optimization.
speakers.tagline: Senior Consultant - Artificial Intelligence & Data Analytics at Lufthansa Industry Solutions

sessions.title: AI Pair Programming with GitHub Copilot at SAP: Looking Back, Looking Forward!
sessions.description: AI Pair Programming with GitHub Copilot is a major milestone in reimagining the developer experience for over 20,000 enterprise software developers at SAP, the world’s largest provider of enterprise application software. SAP kickstarted the adoption of generative AI at scale in internal development with GitHub Copilot which created trust in the output and ease of use of AI tools. Join us as Sumeet Shetty (SAP) and Alexander Trusheim (Microsoft) show you how GitHub Copilot is widely accepted as an AI pair programming tool that brings flow, creativity, and fun into software development at SAP!

speakers.bio: Sumeet Shetty is the Head of Tools India | Engineering Processes & Solutions at SAP, where his current focus is on scaling AI pair programming to over 20,000 developers. He has been part of various strategic initiatives at SAP, including product development for the financial industry, the global rollout of lean and agile software development, design thinking, and business model innovation. He has been a speaker at Microsoft ALM Days, GitHub Universe, SAP d-com, SAP TechEd, the British Council, the India International Center, and the National Gallery of Modern Art. Sumeet is president of Literati, India's largest corporate book club, and has interviewed some of the world's finest authors, thinkers, and leaders. His passions include AI, leadership, art, design, literature, and public speaking. Harvard Business Review described him as “an exceptional leader and coach, recognized for his track record of building high-performance teams
speakers.tagline: Head of Engineering Processes & Solutions - Tools India at SAP

speakers.bio: Alexander Trusheim is a Senior Cloud Solution Architect at Microsoft, focused on enabling developer communities to thrive in a fast-changing world of AI-infused solution development. With a strong background in IT consulting, he brings strategic insight and hands-on experience to his role, committed to helping customers unlock the full potential of modern technologies to achieve their individual goals.
speakers.tagline: Sr. Cloud Solution Architect at Microsoft

sessions.title: When Vision Becomes Legacy: Generational Change in Family Businesses
sessions.description: TBA

speakers.bio:
Johanna Heise is Head of Brand at heise, thus responsible for the employer and general branding of the entire heise group. Additionally, she is active in the executive circle of the heise academy and CEO of heise ventures. 

Before her time in the family business, she gained experience in consulting at KPMG in Deal Advisory and at Simon-Kucher. She completed her Master in Management at ESCP Business School in London, Berlin, and Madrid. Here, she focused on the management of family businesses, international management, and on sales and marketing. Previously, she completed her Bachelor's degree at WHU Otto Beisheim School of Management.

sessions.title: From Feedback to Feedforward: How AI is Transforming Performance Conversations
sessions.description: TBA

speakers.bio:
I’m Dr. Nilima Gandhi, seasoned HR leader and a researcher specializing in TA and leadership development topics. 

With 15+ years of global experience across India, Middle East, and Europe, I bring a unique blend of corporate HR strategy, academic insight, and design thinking to build inclusive, high-performing teams in tech startups.
Currently heading the HR function at Zellerfeld where the core HR challenge lies in creating a cohesive people function from scratch. With no legacy HR systems or processes in place, the task is to architect foundational structures recruiting pipelines, onboarding, performance frameworks, and compliance while maintaining the creative agility of a startup.

Outside work, I’m a trained Bharatnatyam dancer and mountaineering enthusiast, passionate about storytelling and human connection in digital workspaces.

sessions.title: NVIDIA Expert Session: Customize Generative AI Models for Industry-Specific Solutions
sessions.description: Visit us at booth A-16 to get answers to your most pressing questions from NVIDIA technology experts, and claim a free self-paced DLI course on July 10-11.

speakers.bio: Lavinia Ghita is a senior solutions architect for the financial services industry (FSI) at NVIDIA. Her work at NVIDIA focuses on applied AI research and driving the adoption of AI-driven technologies in the financial sector. Prior to joining NVIDIA, Lavinia worked on natural language processing research and applications in a quant hedge fund and in big tech.

Miguel Martínez is a senior deep learning data scientist at NVIDIA, specializing in Generative AI, Recommender Systems, and Data Analytics. He is currently advancing his expertise in large language models with NVIDIA’s Advanced Deep Learning Research team, working on LLM training. Previously, he mentored students in Udacity’s Artificial Intelligence Nanodegree and brings strong experience in financial services, especially payments and channels. A dedicated, lifelong learner, Miguel is always eager to embrace new challenges.
speakers.tagline: Sr. Deep Learning Data Scientist at NVIDIA

speakers.bio: Sergio Perez specializes in conversational AI. He has experience in optimizing training and inference of LLMs, building retrieval-augmented generation systems, and working with companies in different sectors to leverage AI. His area of expertise at NVIDIA is quantization and inference serving. Previously, he worked as an AI engineer at Graphcore and Amazon, and got a Ph.D. in computational fluid dynamics from Imperial College London.

sessions.title: Kill Switch or Moral Compass: Who Programs AI’s Conscience?
sessions.description:
Artificial intelligence increasingly shapes our societies. As systems gain autonomy, one central question arises: Who bears ethical responsibility for algorithmic decisions?

Are developers merely responsible for building systems with a "kill switch"—and using it in emergencies—or is that even possible? Should they instead proactively embed a moral compass into their code? This keynote explores how developers can integrate ethical responsibility into real-world practice.

Through case studies—from algorithmic bias to autonomous vehicles and generative AI—we examine how ethical principles can be applied early in development. We'll discuss international frameworks and hands-on tools for responsible AI.

Developers, tech leads, and decision-makers are invited to see ethics not as a constraint but as a driver of innovation. The real decisions aren’t made by the code itself—but by those who write it.

speakers.bio: Torsten Stiller is a seasoned tech leader and speaker, currently heading the Automation Factory Domain at E.ON Digital Technology. A former Microsoft and NVIDIA professional, he brings deep experience in cloud-native platforms, automation, and digital transformation. Torsten is passionate about the responsible use of AI and sustainable software engineering, combining hands-on expertise with strategic vision to drive ethical, impactful innovation.
speakers.tagline: Head of Automation Factory at E.ON

sessions.title: What's (new) with Spring Boot and Containers?
sessions.description:
Spring Boot has established as the most popular framework for Java applications, while containers have become a standard in many aspects of modern software development. Now, how well do they go together?
